case_name: Tirumalachetti Rajaram v. his father and several alienees

facts.text: Appellant Tirumalachetti Rajaram filed a suit in forma pauperis in the Court of the Subordinate Judge, Chittoor.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant Tirumalachetti Rajaram filed a suit in forma pauperis in the Court of the Subordinate Judge, Chittoor, for his half share in the properties which once belonged to the joint family companysisting of himself and his father and to this suit he impleaded his father and several alienees from him.

facts.text: Suit was for appellant's half share in properties which once belonged to the joint family consisting of himself and his father.

anchor.surface_text: for his half share in the properties which once belonged to the joint family companysisting of himself and his father and to this suit he impleaded his father and several alienees from him. His case was that the alienations effected by him father as well as the sales held in execution proceedings against his father were number binding on him and so his share in the properties companyered by the said alienations was number affected by them.

facts.text: Appellant impleaded his father and several alienees from him in the suit.

anchor.surface_text: and to this suit he impleaded his father and several alienees from him. His case was that the alienations effected by him father as well as the sales held in execution proceedings against his father were number binding on him and so his share in the properties companyered by the said alienations was number affected by them. It is on this basis that he claimed his half share in all the said properties.

facts.text: Appellant's case was that alienations effected by his father and sales held in execution proceedings against his father were not binding on him.

anchor.surface_text: His case was that the alienations effected by him father as well as the sales held in execution proceedings against his father were number binding on him and so his share in the properties companyered by the said alienations was number affected by them. It is on this basis that he claimed his half share in all the said properties. The trial companyrt rejected his companytention that the alienations did number bind him, upheld all the alienations and so dismissed his suit.

facts.text: Trial court rejected appellant's contention that alienations did not bind him, upheld all alienations and dismissed the suit.

anchor.surface_text: The trial companyrt rejected his companytention that the alienations did number bind him, upheld all the alienations and so dismissed his suit. On appeal the High Court of Madras reversed the trial companyrts decree in respect of alienations which companyered items 2, 10 and 14 in Schedule A as well as item 5 in the Schedule B.

facts.text: High Court of Madras reversed trial court's decree in respect of alienations covering items 2, 10 and 14 in Schedule A and item 5 in Schedule B.

anchor.surface_text: On appeal the High Court of Madras reversed the trial companyrts decree in respect of alienations which companyered items 2, 10 and 14 in Schedule A as well as item 5 in the Schedule B. It held that the alienations in respect of these items did number bind the appellants share and so a preliminary decree for partition was passed in his favour in respect of the said items.

facts.text: High Court held that alienations in respect of items 2, 10, 14 Schedule A and 5 Schedule B did not bind appellant's share.

anchor.surface_text: It held that the alienations in respect of these items did number bind the appellants share and so a preliminary decree for partition was passed in his favour in respect of the said items. The rest of the decree passed by the trial companyrt was companyfirmed.

facts.text: High Court passed preliminary decree for partition in favour of appellant in respect of items 2, 10, 14 Schedule A and 5 Schedule B.

anchor.surface_text: and so a preliminary decree for partition was passed in his favour in respect of the said items. The rest of the decree passed by the trial companyrt was companyfirmed. The appellant then applied to the High Court for a certificate under Art. 133 1  of the Constitution.

facts.text: High Court confirmed the rest of the trial court's decree.

anchor.surface_text: The rest of the decree passed by the trial companyrt was companyfirmed. The appellant then applied to the High Court for a certificate under Art. 133 1  of the Constitution. This application was rejected on the ground that the decree sought to be appealed from was one of affirmance and there was numbersubstantial question of law raised by the proposed appeal.

facts.text: Appellant applied to High Court for certificate under Art. 133(1) of the Constitution.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant then applied to the High Court for a certificate under Art. 133 1  of the Constitution. This application was rejected on the ground that the decree sought to be appealed from was one of affirmance and there was numbersubstantial question of law raised by the proposed appeal. In companying to this companyclusion the High Court followed an earlier Full Bench decision in Chittam Subba Rao v. Vela Mankanni Chilamayya I.L.R. 1953 Mad. 1.

facts.text: High Court rejected appellant's application for certificate on ground that decree was one of affirmance and no substantial question of law.

anchor.surface_text: This application was rejected on the ground that the decree sought to be appealed from was one of affirmance and there was numbersubstantial question of law raised by the proposed appeal. facts.text: High Court followed Full Bench decision in Chittam Subba Rao v. Vela Mankanni Chilamayya I.L.R. 1953 Mad. 1.

anchor.surface_text: In companying to this companyclusion the High Court followed an earlier Full Bench decision in Chittam Subba Rao v. Vela Mankanni Chilamayya I.L.R. 1953 Mad. 1. facts.text: Appellant obtained special leave from Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant then applied for and obtained special leave from this Court, and on his behalf it is urged that the view taken by the Madras High Court in the case of Chittam Subba Rao I.L.R. 1953 Mad. 1 proceeds on a misconstruction of the relevant clause in Art. 133 1 . facts.text: High Courts show sharp conflict on whether appellate decree varying in favour of intending appellant is decree of affirmance.

anchor.surface_text: The decisions of the High Courts, however, show a sharp companyflict in regard to the question as to the character of the appellate decree where it makes a variation in favour of the intending appellant. Broadly stated the majority of the High Courts have taken the view that an appellate decree which makes a variation in favour of the intending appellant is a decree of affirmance and it is only the Punjab High Court and the majority decision of the Patna High Court which have taken a companytrary view.

facts.text: Madras High Court Full Bench in Chittam Subba Rao v. Vela Mankanni Chilamayya I.L.R. 1953 Mad. 1 held appellate decree varying in favour is affirmance.

anchor.surface_text: In companying to this companyclusion the High Court followed an earlier Full Bench decision in Chittam Subba Rao v. Vela Mankanni Chilamayya I.L.R. 1953 Mad. 1.

facts.text: Punjab High Court and majority Patna High Court took contrary view to majority High Courts on affirmance.

anchor.surface_text: Broadly stated the majority of the High Courts have taken the view that an appellate decree which makes a variation in favour of the intending appellant is a decree of affirmance and it is only the Punjab High Court and the majority decision of the Patna High Court which have taken a companytrary view.

facts.text: Supreme Court holds that appellate decree must be considered as a whole to determine if it affirms trial court decision.

facts.text: If appellate decree varies trial court decision, it is not a decree of affirmance regardless of favour or extent.

anchor.surface_text: That is the proper approach in applying the test of affirmance. facts.text: Supreme Court allows appeal, sets aside High Court order refusing certificate, remands for disposal.

anchor.surface_text: The result is the appeal must be allowed, the order passed by the High Court by which the appellants application for certificate has been refused must be set aside and the matter sent back to the High Court for disposal in accordance with law.

prescribed by Art. 133 1  a  is satisfied in this case. Article 133 1  which corresponds to s. 110 of the Code of Civil Procedure reads thus

Article 133 1  which corresponds to s. 110 of the Code of Civil Procedure reads thus 133 1 . An appeal shall lie to the Supreme Court from any judgment, decree or final order in a civil proceeding of a High Court in the territory of India if the High Court certifies -  a  that the amount or value of the subject matter of the dispute in the court of first instance and still in dispute on appeal was and is not less than twenty thousand rupees or such other sum as may be specified in that behalf by Parliament by law or  b  that the judgment, decree or final order involves directly or indirectly some claim or question respecting property of the like amount or value or  c  that the case is a fit one for appeal to the Supreme Court and, where the judgment, decree or final order appealed from affirms the decision of the court immediately below in any case other than a case referred to in sub-clause  c , if the High Court further certifies that the appeal involves some substantial question of law.

arguments.claim: Normal rule: one decree per suit; splitting unreasonable

anchor.surface_text: Normally, in each suit there is one decree, and so it would be inconsistent with the scheme of the Code to divide the decree into several parts by reference to its relation to different claims or subject-matters or to treat one single decree as consisting in fact of several decrees.

holdings.text: In determining the question as to whether the appellate decree passed by the High Court affirmed the decision of the trial court the appellate decree must be considered as a whole in relation to the decision of the trial court similarly considered as a whole. That is the proper approach in applying the test of affirmance. If there is a variation made in the appellate decree in the decision of the trial court it is not a decree of affirmance and this is not affected either by the extent of the variation made or by the fact that the variation is made in favour of the intending appellant and not against him.

anchor.surface_text: We would accordingly hold that in determining the question as to whether the appellate decree passed by the High Court affirmed the decision of the trial court the appellate decree must be considered as a whole in relation to the decision of the trial court similarly considered as a whole. That is the proper approach in applying the test of affirmance.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Plain grammatical meaning of Art. 133(1); harmonious construction equating 'decree' and 'decision' as wholes; Privy Council precedent on 'decision' as suit outcome not grounds; rejects partial decree/decision arguments, High Court majority view, policy anomalies; resolves conflicts.

holdings.text: Both the decree and the decision referred to in the clause mean the decree and the decision respectively taken as a whole and not in part.

anchor.surface_text: Therefore, we are inclined to hold that both the decree and the decision referred to in the clause mean the decree and the decision respectively taken as a whole and not in part.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Context requires whole to harmonize 'decree' (one per suit normally) and 'decision'; rejects O.20 rr.4-5, O.41 r.33 splitting; Privy Council confirms 'decision' as whole suit.

holdings.text: If an appellate decree confirms the decision of the trial court but merely makes a variation in regard to the order as to costs such a variation would not affect the character of the decree which would in law amount to a decree of affirmance.

anchor.surface_text: Before we part with this appeal we would like to make it clear that if an appellate decree confirms the decision of the trial court but merely makes a variation in regard to the order as to costs such a variation would not affect the character of the decree which would in law amount to a decree of affirmance,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Costs discretionary under s.35 CPC, unlike merits; obiter clarification.

holdings.text: The position with regard to interest, however, is different for instance, in regard to a claim for interest before the date of the decree which is a part of the dispute between the parties if the appellate court makes a variation in respect of the award of interest that would affect the character of the appellate decree. Unlike the order of costs which is entirely in the discretion of the Court under s. 35 of the Code of Civil Procedure an order as to interest which the Court can make under s. 34 of the Code forms part of a dispute between the parties.

anchor.surface_text: The position with regard to interest, however, is different for instance, in regard to a claim for interest before the date of the decree which is a part of the dispute between the parties if the appellate court makes a variation in respect of the award of interest that would affect the character of the appellate decree.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Interest under s.34 CPC integral to parties' dispute unlike discretionary costs; obiter.

holdings.text: If the appeal court makes a variation in the decision of the trial court either because a concession has been made in that behalf or the variation has been obtained by parties by consent or a part of the subject-matter covered by the decree has been withdrawn such variation cannot affect the character of the appellate decree.

anchor.surface_text: In this connection it may also be necessary to make it clear that if the appeal court makes a variation in the decision of the trial court either because a concession has been made in that behalf or the variation has been obtained by parties by consent or a part of the subject-matter covered by the decree has been withdrawn such variation cannot affect the character of the appellate decree.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Affirmance doctrine requires adjudication on merits, not consent/withdrawal; obiter.

precedents.citation: Chittam Subba Rao v. Vela Mankanni Chilamayya I.L.R. 1953 Mad. 1

anchor.surface_text: In coming to this conclusion the High Court followed an earlier Full Bench decision in Chittam Subba Rao v. Vela Mankanni Chilamayya I.L.R. 1953 Mad. 1.

precedents.case_name: Chittam Subba Rao v Vela Mankanni Chilamayya
precedents.cited_proposition: appellate decree making variation in favour of intending appellant is still a decree of affirmance

precedents.citation: Dhirendra Nath Sarkar v. Nischintapore Company 1916 36 I.C. 398 2 C.W.N. 192

anchor.surface_text: In support of the argument that there can be more decrees than one in a suit which combines different causes of action and different claims made against different defendants in respect of different subject matters Mr. Tatachari, for the respondent, has relied on the decision of the Calcutta High Court in Dhirendra Nath Sarkar v. Nischintapore Company 1916 36 I.C. 398 2 C.W.N. 192.

precedents.case_name: Dhirendra Nath Sarkar v Nischintapore Company
precedents.cited_proposition: one decree covering multiple tenancies treated as separate decrees for limitation under Art. 182 Expl. 1

precedents.citation: Rajah Tasadduq Rasul Khan v. Manik Chand 1902 L.R. 30 I.A. 35

anchor.surface_text: The question as to the meaning of the word decision in the corresponding provision of the Code of 1882 (s. 596) was considered by the Privy Council in Rajah Tasadduq Rasul Khan v. Manik Chand 1902 L.R. 30 I.A. 35.

precedents.case_name: Rajah Tasadduq Rasul Khan v Manik Chand
precedents.cited_proposition: decision means the decision of the suit as a whole, not merely the grounds or part of it
precedents.cited_holding: appellate decree affirming trial court's decision though on different grounds is decree of affirmance

precedents.citation: Raja Sree Nath Roy Bahadur v. The Secretary of State for India in Council 1904 8 C.W.N. 294

anchor.surface_text: In Raja Sree Nath Roy Bahadur v. The Secretary of State for India in Council 1904 8 C.W.N. 294 a Full Bench of the Calcutta High Court had occasion to consider the effect of the relevant provisions of s. 596 of the Code of 1882.

precedents.case_name: Raja Sree Nath Roy Bahadur v The Secretary of State for India in Council
precedents.cited_proposition: decree is of affirmance as regards the subject-matter of the proposed appeal even if varied in appellant's favour on other aspects

anchor.surface_text: The same point was raised before the Privy Council in Annapurnabai v. Ruprao 1924 L.R. 51 I.A. 319.

precedents.cited_proposition: appellate decree varying trial court's decision even in favour of intending appellant is not a decree of affirmance
precedents.cited_holding: petitioners had right of appeal under s. 110 despite variation in their favour

precedents.citation: Narendra Lal Das Chaudhury v. Gopendra Lal Das Chaudhury A.I.R. 1927 Cal. 543

anchor.surface_text: Three years later the same question arose before the Calcutta High Court in Narendra Lal Das Chaudhury v. Gopendra Lal Das Chaudhury A.I.R. 1927 Cal. 543.

precedents.case_name: Narendra Lal Das Chaudhury v Gopendra Lal Das Chaudhury
precedents.cited_proposition: Annapurnabai limited to cases where amount is in dispute; otherwise look to substance of appeal

precedents.citation: V. Lakshminarayana Sastry v. V. Sitaramma Sastry

anchor.surface_text: The Madras view has been applied by the Andhra High Court in V. Lakshminarayana Sastry v. V. Sitaramma Sastry .

precedents.case_name: V Lakshminarayana Sastry v V Sitaramma Sastry
precedents.cited_proposition: applied Madras Full Bench view on affirmance despite variation in favour

precedents.citation: Rani Fateh Kunwar v. Raja Durbijai Singh I.L.R. 1952 2 All. 605

anchor.surface_text: The majority judgment of the Allahabad High Court in Rani Fateh Kunwar v. Raja Durbijai Singh I.L.R. 1952 2 All. 605 which in fact preceded the Madras decision has adopted substantially the same approach and has come to the same conclusion.

precedents.case_name: Rani Fateh Kunwar v Raja Durbijai Singh
precedents.cited_proposition: adopted approach similar to Madras on affirmance

precedents.citation: G.C. Bardoloi v. Collector of Kamrup A.I.R. 1952 Ass. 134

anchor.surface_text: To the same effect are the decisions of the Assam, Bombay, Mysore and Nagpur High Courts vide G.C. Bardoloi v. Collector of Kamrup A.I.R. 1952 Ass. 134 Kapurji Magniram v. Pannaji Debichand 31 B.L.R. 619...

precedents.case_name: GC Bardoloi v Collector of Kamrup
precedents.cited_proposition: took view similar to Allahabad majority on affirmance test

anchor.surface_text: The Calcutta High Court has generally adopted the view taken by Rankin, C.J., but as its decision in Probodh Chandra Roy v. Hara Hari Roy , shows the practice in the Calcutta High Court appears to be to treat the point as one of doubt...

precedents.cited_proposition: Calcutta practice treats point as one of doubt, resolving in favour of applicant

Kanahaya Lal Sham Lal I.L.R. 1957 Punj. 255 and the majority decision of the Patna High Court in Kanak Sunder v. Ram Lakhan I.L.R. 1956 35 Pat. 499 have taken the view which we have adopted.

precedents.cited_proposition: appellate decree with variation is not one of affirmance

anchor.surface_text: We would accordingly hold that in determining the question as to whether the appellate decree passed by the High Court affirmed the decision of the trial court the appellate decree must be considered as a whole in relation to the decision of the trial court similarly considered as a whole. That is the proper approach in applying the test of affirmance.
